bestBHT.bht: Paul, bound with two chains, stood before an angry crowd, while the Roman commander sat nearby, maintaining order. With a calm and self-possessed demeanor, Paul spoke in the Hebrew tongue, the vernacular language of the Palestine Jews at the time, in order to connect with and be better understood by the multitude. The crowd, filled with rage, was silenced by the sound of their beloved Hebrew words. This was a pivotal moment for Paul, facing a unique audience and defending himself against familiar accusations.

Henry Alford: in the Hebrew tongue... that they might be the more disposed to listen to him.
The Syro-Chaldaic, the mother-tongue of the Jews in Judæa at this time.
His motive is implied (ch. xxii. 2) to be.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: What nobler spectacle than that of Paul at this moment! There he stood, bound with two chains, ready to make his defense to the people. The Roman commander sits by, to enforce order by his presence. An enraged populace look up to him from below. Yet in the midst of so many dangers, how self-possessed is he, how tranquil!
A great silence—the people awed at the permission given him by the commandant, and seeing him sitting as a listener.
In the Hebrew tongue—the Syro-Chaldaic, the vernacular tongue of the Palestine Jews since the captivity.
Albert Barnes: Beckoned with the hand - Waving the hand as a sign that he was about to address them, and to produce silence and attention." (15 words)
In the Hebrew tongue - This language he doubtless used on this occasion in preference to the Greek, because it was understood better by the multitude." (27 words)
The following chapter should have been connected with this. The division here is unnatural." (16 words)
Marvin Vincent: Beckoned with the hand. Compare ch. 26 1.
Tongue [διαλεκτω] . Lit., dialect : the language spoken by the Palestinian Jews - a mixture of Syriac and Chaldaic.
Philip Schaff: We have in these 'Acts' several marked instances of this strange power Paul gained so quickly over those with whom he was brought into contact.

The face and form of the speaker may have been seen from time to time by some during his passing visits to Jerusalem, but there must have been many who had not heard him take any part in public action since the day when, nearly a quarter of a century before, he had kept the garments of those who were stoning Stephen; and now he was there, accused of the self-same crimes, making his defence before a crowd as wild and frenzied as that of which he had then been the leader.

That is, he spoke this address to his fellow-countrymen in that Hebrew dialect, the Syro-Chaldaic or Aramaic, the mother-tongue of the Jews in Judæa at that time...No doubt 'the great silence,' the hush which fell on this angry, vociferating crowd, was produced by the sound of the loved Hebrew words.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul had faced many audiences and crowds, but never one quite like this.
Paul knows only too well what this mob thinks of him.
Self-possessed with majestic poise Paul faces the outraged mob beneath the stairs.
John Gill: ...and beckoned with the hand unto the people...
...he spake unto them in the Hebrew tongue...
John Wesley: In the Hebrew tongue — That dialect of it, which was then commonly spoken at Jerusalem.
